Those "little spools" are bobbins. They are not meant to be used on the needle. They provide the thread from the bottom and, since that thread is essentially just a straight line of thread, it doesn't use as much as the needle does. That said, there is nothing stopping you from using it like a spool on top if you don't mind having to refill them more often.

So Barthelemy Thimonnier created one of the first successful sewing machines. He had a factory that mainly sewed uniforms for the French army... at a very quick pace. Other tailors in the area got scared because he was taking their jobs, so they all came together and burned down his factory... with him in it. Thimonnier survived, rebuilt, and they did it again. He survived the second murder attempt as well.

I like to think I'm fairly smart because I can build PCs, 3D printers and other gadgets but one day I ended up in a sewing machine repair shop (my mom had to get her machine fixed) and I saw the guts of a few sewing machines and was quite humbled. That fact that you can "tell" the machine what kind of stitch you want it to do just by flipping a switch and it will do it though sheer physical mechanics, not a transistor, IC or servo anywhere.

One more random fact: originally a scroll saws/jigsaws were just modified sewing machines. Bottom part with the bobine was removed and the needle was replaced with a small saw blade.
As for actual sewing machines, i had the pleasure to work with a 1929 Singer machine that was retrofitted with a motor instead of that one big pedal. It sounded like a train and honestly felt like one, but would sew anything from fine silk to thick warm blankets with no problems. Really awesome machine!

Thank you for the explanation of the mechanism. It made sense and was actually interesting to learn about.

I always like to make comparisons and links between different concepts. I realised how the sewing machine works because of the bobbin. In weaving, yarn or string is held on a shuttle or sometimes a bobbin. In bobbin lace making, the threads are held on bobbins and moved around. So with that information I deduced that the bobbin holds and moves the thread around hence coming to the realisation that the bobbin in a sewing machine goes through a loop created by the top thread.
